title: 107_hr1176
content: The "Fair Credit Reporting Act Amendments of 2001" allow consumers to request a free credit report annually from consumer reporting agencies. This amendment also requires disclosures to be made without charge to consumers at least once each calendar year. The Fair Credit Reporting Act Amendments of 2001 allow consumers to request a free credit report annually from consumer reporting agencies. Section 609(c)(1)(B) is amended to include disclosure of World Wide Web site information for consumer contact. Additionally, there is a requirement for disclosure of credit scores and explanations. SEC. 4. Amends the Fair Credit Reporting Act to require disclosure of credit scores and explanations, including a summary of how scores are derived, factors considered, application to the consumer, weight of each factor, and impact on the score. SEC. 5 amends the Fair Credit Reporting Act to allow exclusion of small debts under certain conditions if the amount is under $100, more than 3 years old, and the consumer completed a credit and financial management class within that period. SEC. 6 requires prompt investigation and correction or deletion of inaccurate, incomplete, or unverifiable consumer information. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System and the Federal Trade Commission are required to review and monitor consumer reporting agencies and furnishers of consumer information to ensure compliance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act. They must submit a progress report to Congress within 6 months on the results of this review. The report under subsection (b) will include recommendations for legislative or administrative action to ensure prompt investigation and correction of consumer disputes with reporting agencies, compliance by furnishers of information, and establishment of internal controls by reporting agencies. The curr_chunk discusses the importance of internal controls and management review procedures to ensure compliance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act for investigating and correcting inaccurate consumer information. Definitions for terms like "consumer report" are also provided. The amendments made by this Act will be effective at the end of the 90-day period from the enactment date.
